newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Prodi sees economic upturn by summer.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Prodi sees economic upturn by summer.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi said on Thursday Italy had succeeded in slashing inflation and could now look forward to an upturn in economic growth by the summer.
"The battle against inflation has been won and in the next few months I can assure you it will not grow," Prodi told a meeting of the Italian housewives association.
Italian inflation fell to 1.7 percent year-on-year in April from 2.2 percent in March -- the lowest rate for 28 years.

"There are already concrete signs that the economy is changing tack. The time of holding back, of tight economic conditions is behind us," Prodi said. "In the next few months, around summer, we will see the signs of an economic pick-up.
"They will be small but concrete," he added.

The Italian economy grew 0.7 percent in 1996. The Italian industrialists' federation said in a report released on Wednesday that they expected around zero gross domestic product growth in the first quarter of 1997. -- Rome Newsroom +396 678 2501
